title: Back Pain Decision Support
description: Get personalized guidance on managing your back pain and understanding treatment options.
welcome_message:
Welcome! We're here to help you understand your back pain and explore treatment options.

This will take about 5-10 minutes. Your answers will help us provide more relevant information.
system_prompt_template: You are a compassionate healthcare assistant helping a patient with back pain. The patient has reported: Duration: {duration}, Pain Level: {pain_level}, Previous treatments: {treatments_tried}. Location: {pain_location}. The patients goals are {goals}. Provide evidence-based information about treatment options, focusing on shared decision making. Be empathetic and informative, but try to limit the length of responses and end with questions in order to encourage dialogue.

onboarding_questions.text: Do you have any of the following symptoms?

options.label: Weakness in my legs -- can't lift either of them
Numbness in my pelvic / groin region
None
options.description: None of the above listed conditions

onboarding_questions.text: How long have you been experiencing back pain?
How would you rate your pain on average?

options.label: Mild (1-3)
options.description: Noticeable but doesn't interfere much with activities

onboarding_questions.text: Where is your pain primarily located?

options.label: Back pain that radiates to legs

onboarding_questions.text: What treatments have you already tried?
What are your main goals for managing your back pain?
onboarding_questions.placeholder: For example: return to work, play with grandchildren, sleep better...

options.title: Physical Therapy
options.description: A program of exercises and stretches designed by a physical therapist to strengthen your back, improve flexibility, and reduce pain.
benefits: Can be done at home after initial training
drawbacks: Requires regular time commitment (typically 2-3x per week)
Results may take 6-12 weeks to become noticeable
May require co-pay for each session
Success depends on patient compliance with exercises
options.typical_timeline: 6-12 weeks of sessions, then ongoing home exercises

options.title: Medication Management
options.description: Using over-the-counter or prescription medications to manage pain and inflammation.
benefits: Multiple options available (NSAIDs, muscle relaxants, etc.)
Can be combined with other treatments
drawbacks: Risk of dependency with some medications
Not a long-term solution on its own
options.typical_timeline: Immediate relief, but ongoing management needed

options.title: Spinal Injections
options.description: Corticosteroid injections delivered directly to the affected area of the spine to reduce inflammation and pain.
benefits: Targeted treatment to the problem area
May allow participation in physical therapy
drawbacks: Limited number of injections per year
Does not fix underlying structural issues

options.title: Spine Surgery
options.description: Surgical intervention to address structural problems in the spine, such as herniated discs or spinal stenosis.
benefits: Can provide lasting relief for specific conditions
May be the only effective option for some conditions
Modern techniques are less invasive than before
drawbacks: Typically reserved for cases that don't respond to other treatments
options.typical_timeline: Recovery 6 weeks to 6 months depending on procedure

options.title: Watchful Waiting / Self-Care
options.description: Monitoring symptoms while using self-care strategies like rest, heat/ice, gentle stretching, and activity modification.
benefits: Many cases of back pain resolve on their own
Can try other options if pain persists
drawbacks: Not appropriate for severe or worsening symptoms
options.typical_timeline: 4-6 weeks to see if symptoms improve naturally
options.success_rate: 80-90% of acute back pain resolves within 6 weeks

conversation_points.title: Recognize a decision exists
conversation_points.description: Helping the patient understand that they have a choice to make and what the decision involves
conversation_points.curiosity_prompt: I want to make sure you know you have options here
conversation_points.system_message_template: Help the patient understand they have an active decision to make about their back pain treatment. Explain that multiple valid approaches exist and their input matters in choosing the right path.
elicitation_goals: Confirm the patient understands this is THEIR decision to make
Assess their current understanding of available treatment approaches
Identify if they feel pressured toward any particular option
Understand who else (family, other doctors) might be involved in their decision
example_questions: Before we dive into specifics, I want to make sure you know that how we approach your back pain is ultimately your choice. Did you know there are several different treatment paths we could consider?
Has anyone already suggested a particular treatment to you? I want to make sure you're aware of all your options.
Is there anyone else - a family member, or another doctor - who you'd want to include in thinking through this decision?
What's your understanding so far of what can be done for back pain like yours?
semantic_keywords: I didn't know I could choose
suggested_questions: What decision am I being asked to make?
Do I have to decide right now?
Who else should be involved in this decision?

conversation_points.title: Discuss available options
conversation_points.description: Presenting all relevant treatment options including conservative approaches and doing nothing
conversation_points.curiosity_prompt: Let me walk you through what treatments are available
conversation_points.system_message_template: Walk the patient through the treatment options available for their back pain. Cover the full spectrum from conservative (self-care, physical therapy) to more intensive (injections, surgery), including watchful waiting. Gauge their interest in learning more about specific options.
elicitation_goals: Ensure patient is aware of ALL major treatment categories (not just one or two)
Identify which options they've already heard about or considered
Discover which options they want to learn more about
Understand if any options are already ruled out in their mind (and why)
example_questions: There are several approaches we can consider: self-care and watchful waiting, physical therapy, medications, injections, and in some cases surgery. Which of these have you already heard about?
Are there any treatments you've already ruled out, or any you're particularly interested in exploring?
Some people prefer to start with the least invasive options and see how they do. Others want to be more aggressive. What's your initial instinct?
Is there anything you've read or heard about back pain treatments that you'd like me to address?
suggested_questions: What are all my treatment options?
What happens if I do nothing?
Which option do most people choose?

conversation_points.title: Understand benefits and harms
conversation_points.description: Explaining the pros, cons, and probabilities of outcomes for each option, tailored to the patient's situation
conversation_points.curiosity_prompt: I'd like to help you understand the pros and cons
conversation_points.system_message_template: Help the patient understand the specific benefits, risks, and trade-offs of the treatment options they're considering. Tailor the discussion to their situation (pain level, duration, previous treatments). Be honest about uncertainties and success rates.
elicitation_goals: Identify which specific options they want benefit/risk information about
Understand their biggest concerns or fears about treatment
Assess their tolerance for risk vs. their desire for quick results
Clarify any misconceptions about treatment outcomes
example_questions: Which treatment options would you like to know more about in terms of what could go well and what could go wrong?
When you think about treating your back pain, what worries you the most?
Are you more concerned about potential side effects, or about whether a treatment will actually work?
Some treatments offer quicker relief but may not last as long. Others take time but address the root cause. How do you feel about that trade-off?
Have you heard anything about these treatments - good or bad - that you'd like me to confirm or correct?
suggested_questions: What are the risks of this treatment?
How likely is it to work?
What side effects should I expect?

conversation_points.title: Clarify your values and preferences
conversation_points.description: Helping the patient identify and articulate what matters most to them in making this decision
conversation_points.curiosity_prompt: I'd like to understand what matters most to you
conversation_points.system_message_template: Help the patient explore and articulate what matters most to them as they consider their options. Focus on understanding their goals, priorities, and what they want to avoid. Connect their values to how different treatment options might serve them.
elicitation_goals: Identify 2-3 specific activities they want to resume or maintain
Understand their timeline expectations or constraints
Learn what outcomes they most want to avoid (e.g., surgery, dependency on meds)
Discover how this decision fits into their broader life circumstances
example_questions: What activities has your back pain stopped you from doing that you most want to get back to?
Is there a timeline that matters to you - an event coming up, a goal you're working toward?
When you imagine the best possible outcome, what does that look like for you?
Is there anything you really want to avoid - whether that's a particular treatment, a side effect, or an outcome?
How does this fit with everything else going on in your life right now? Are there other health issues, work demands, or family situations I should know about?
suggested_questions: How do I figure out what's most important to me?
What questions should I ask myself?
How does this fit with my lifestyle?

conversation_points.title: Weigh your options
conversation_points.description: Supporting the patient in weighing trade-offs and considering how options align with their values
conversation_points.curiosity_prompt: Let's think through which option fits you best
conversation_points.system_message_template: Help the patient weigh their options against their values and priorities. Summarize what you've learned about their situation and preferences, then help them see how each option aligns (or doesn't) with what matters to them. Support them in moving toward a decision without pressuring them.
elicitation_goals: Identify which option(s) they're leaning toward
Surface any remaining uncertainties or questions
Understand what would help them feel confident in a decision
Determine their readiness to make a decision or need for more time/input
example_questions: Based on everything we've discussed, is there an option that feels like it might be right for you?
What questions or concerns are still on your mind as you think about this decision?
What would help you feel more confident about choosing a path forward?
Would it help to talk through how [specific option] aligns with your goal of [specific goal they mentioned]?
Do you feel ready to make a decision, or would you like more time to think about it or discuss it with someone?
Is there anything you'd want to ask your doctor before deciding?
suggested_questions: Help me decide between these options...
What would you recommend for someone like me?
What should I ask my doctor?
